  • Events

Events

  • Edit
  • Signal Issue

Events

connectors communicate via events. The following is a list of all the events common to all connectors, with their signature, and the interface they implement.

  • element::<element-type>
  • fetch::end
  • fetch::error
  • fetch::start
  • manifestfetch::end
  • manifestfetch::error
  • manifestfetch::start
  • manifestfetch::missing
  • scan::end
  • scan::start
  • targetfetch::end
  • targetfetch::error
  • targetfetch::start
  • traverse::down
  • traverse::end
  • traverse::start
  • traverse::up

element::<element-type>

Event is emitted when the connector visits an element in the DOM when traversing it. <element-type> is the nodeName lower cased.

Format:

fetch::end

Event is emitted when the connector has finished downloading the content of a resource (js, css, image, etc.).

Format:

Note: This is a basic event interface that targetfetch::end and manifestfetch::end extend from.

fetch::error

Event is emitted when the connector has encountered a problem downloading the content of a resource.

Format:

Note: This event has the same interface as targetfetch::error.

fetch::start

Event is emitted when the connector is about to start the request to fetch the target.

Format:

Note: This is a basic event interface that targetfetch::start extends from.

manifestfetch::end

Event is emitted when the connector has finished downloading the web manifest of a page.

Format:

Note: This event interface extends from fetch::end.

manifestfetch::start

Event is emitted when the connector is about to start downloading the web manifest.

Format:

Note:: This event has the same interface as fetch::start.

manifestfetch::error

Event is emitted when the connector has encountered a problem downloading the web manifest.

Format:

manifestfetch::missing

Event is emitted when the connector hasnâ€™t found any manifest to download.

Format:

scan::end

Event is emitted when the connector has finished sending all events and its about to return. This is the last event to be emitted.

Format:

scan::start

Event is emitted when the connector is about to start the analysis. This is the first event to be emitted.

Format:

Note: This event is fired synchronously. You should not return a Promise because it will not wait for it to be resolved. If you need to perform an async operation you should combine it with scan::end. You can find more information in how to interact with other services.

targetfetch::end

Event is emitted when the connector has finished downloading the target.

Format:

Note: This event interface extends from fetch::end. In this case element will be null.

targetfetch::error

Event is emitted when the connector has encountered a problem downloading the target.

Format:

Note:: This event has the same interface as fetch::error. In this case element will be null.

targetfetch::start

Event is emitted when the connector is about to start the request to fetch the target. Redirects are followed if needed.

Format:

Note:: This event interface extends from fetch::start.

traverse::down

Event is emitted when the connector is traversing and starts visiting the children of a node.

Format:

traverse::end

Event is emitted when the connector has finished traversing the DOM entirely.

Format:

traverse::start

Event is emitted when the connector is going to start traversing the DOM.

Format:

traverse::up

Event is emitted when the connector has finsihed visting the children of a node and goes to the next one.

Format:
